Change the comment at the top also to say 0.9.0.1.

Dialog will require its own VCAP credentials to be stored . They can be retrieved using the Util (see other watson scala tests for example). Be sure to set VCAP_SERVICES property when using open: Set the variable or set the property in whisk.propeties
vcap.services.file=

VCAP_SERVICES property must be set in open ,  or set this property in whisk.propeties;
vcap.services.file=
LGTM
This is now merge, @mdeuser @dubeejw @houshengbo please coordinate to handle the testing in #782
@mdeuser @dubeejw Could you run this on your windows computers and report back?
https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/16468#event-706665661 fixed/closed.

I discuss the proposal with @houshengbo here is my summary:

The split will be `openwhisk` vs `openwhisk-catalog`

## openwhisk

`openwhisk` does not depend on `openwhisk-catalog`
The `catalog` folder doesn't exist anymore
No packages will be install by default (build, deploy, vagrant) on this repo
User will need to manually (or via script) install packages repos
Tests in openwhisk should not depend on any package repos including `openwhisk-catalog`
Any current tests that depend on catalog, should be refactor to use a new test fixture, or move the test to the package repo if it make sense. 
Need to look at each test to see if the test is testing the package, or testing a core functionality

## openwhisk-catalog

`openwhisk-catalog` depends on `openwhisk`
Contain the a core set of packages
Contain the test cases to test the packages
Configured with Travis for CI to run the tests
Any package that requires a credential for testing, it should use the Travis encryption service so test can run automatically in the Travis Cloud
User should be able to run the tests locally by providing his own credentials for the any services that test cases depend on (Slack, Watson, Github, etc..)
To work with the repo an user will do something like this:

```
git clone https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog
cd openwhisk-catalog
git clone https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk
OPENWHISK_HOME=$(cd openwhisk && pwd)
cd $OPENWHISK_HOME
git checkout (pinned hash or master)
.... build and deploy (redo setup prereq couchdb initdb deploy) 
../packages/install.sh $APIHOST $AUTH $WSK_CLI
... use the packages as normal using WSK CLI
... run tests the packages 
edit ../packages/tests/credentials.json 
cp -a ../packages/tests/  tests/src/packages/
gradlew tests:test --tests packages.*
```
Do these changes mean we have to manually set the WHISK_BUILD_TIMESTAMP to get the CLI to have a version?
rebased and merged in 7454e01cf035053813690a619fb0f9ce163e4718

No.  If the `WHISK_BUILD_TIMESTAMP` environment variable is not set, then a current timestamp will be generated and used within the Go CLI build.  The environment variable can be used in local developer builds to cause a much quicker Go CLI build - if it's set and not changed, the Go builds will reuse the build results in the Docker cache.
@rabbah This should be ready to merge now.
@csantanapr I was able to successfully run `./hello` on El Capitan
Not sure that everyone building locally is going to know that that environment variable has to be set in order to cache the Go CLI build.
Right.  When this PR is merged, this step will need to be documented for developers.  Even if not set, the Go CLI build will continue as it does today.
Setting the timestamp inside the Dockerfile would cache the Go CLI build, and wouldn't need any documentation for developers.
Looks like this needs careful rebasing after `7454e01cf035053813690a619fb0f9ce163e4718`
This does not fix the high CPU problem and @danielfederschmidt double-checked and confirmed that it does not fix the high CPU problem.

The final solution will heavily depend on how the overall openwhisk components obtain their build timestamps.  In other projects I've been on, this is centrally controlled by top level build constructs and conveyed to the individual component builds.  That way it's easy to see that a specific combination of components was all built at the same time.  If the Go CLI sets it's build timestamp inside the dockerfile, it will be unique to just the Go CLI.  The solution I chose, assumed the former architecture; however, if that is not how the design plays out, then the Go CLI is free to generated its own build timestamp.
@csantanapr - Ready for merge
@csantanapr - Ready for merge
@dubeejw - Ready for review.  Thanks!

@houshengbo - Are you running on a vagrant VM under Windows?  If so, when cloning the openwhisk repo, the symlink for that bin/wsk file is lost and you will need to re-create that link.  Double check the link with `ls -al openwhisk/bin`.

To add the symlink back, run `cd openwhisk/bin && ln -s ../tools/cli/wsk wsk`

Just thinking... Do we really want to put a security override in an external properties file?  If that file is hacked or accidentally carried forward, the intended security check can be compromised.

If we leave it as a CLI option only, developers can use `alias wsk='wsk -i'`
PPG 713 after latest rebase
i was thinking this is saved in the user's wskprops file. `wsk property set --insecure true`.

I had problems with docker 1.9.1
I think we should use latest GA version of docker on native mac 1.11.2
When I switched to 1.11.2 I had better luck stopping and cleaning kafka container.

I agree with @rabbah on https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/428#issuecomment-229198377
I can add `wsk property set --insecure true` and we can add to the docs, this way it also works for windows users.

I don't think windows has "alias", it's being a while since I used "windows", and we should not assume they will have `bash` or `cygwin`
LGTM
merged 5994caae5f6d97d47de88bddb2d7914bd552e519

@csantanapr I was thinking of having this built into the new you all have for system actions.  If you could have this built into that as a prebuilt action that would be super cool!  Specifically [this new editor.](https://new-console.ng.bluemix.net/openwhisk/editor)
Update the docs also here [docs/reference.md](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/reference.md#runtime-environment)

https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/84030e3669a47aaa6ca0f90ea908e64569be43a3 addresses the last round of issues that I raised. I suggest you freeze your pull request - or i will send you a pull request against your fork with those changes to stash in your commit.

Travis build for changes: https://travis-ci.org/rabbah/openwhisk/builds/140982346

The commit above from #783 doesn't noticeably improve the build as I'm observing that two successive builds with no changes take a `Total time: 2 mins 28.43 secs` (excluding go CLI, two successive builds with no changes take `Total time: 6.582 secs` otherwise).

Indeed - we lost a top level build, deploy, test in the documentation refactoring. It's now buried here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/vagrant/custom#build-and-deploy
and here https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/vagrant/custom#running-tests.

Since we are in the process of removing `ant` and will need to update these documents, we should include a top level build/deploy/test summary.

@csantanapr am I missing some other place where the instructions may be located.

Rebased for conflicting merge.
PPG 715.

Hi @houshengbo. You can setup Travis CI to your fork of openwhisk as well to be able to test experiments like these without cluttering our Pull Requests page too much. Feel free to reach out to me if you need any guidance on how to do that.
PPG 715 approved.
Are these results from your local builds with the `WHISK_BUILD_TIMESTAMP` environment variable set?
Jeff that's what I mean it's already built in, use the Github package with the webhook feed to create a trigger that fires everyone the wiki changes

I ran `ant build` twice in a row - I didn't grok from the comment above that I'm supposed to set the env var myself explicitly. Eh. What do I set it to, when do I change it? I think this just punts the responsibility of managing when the build occurs, for which I might as well pull out the go-cli build from the top gradle file and build it on demand.

Existential question - what if we dropped this build time from the CLI? This was not really the best way to version the CLI anyway.
I'll take this one.  Since the Go CLI and tests are not yet full incorporated right now, I'll add a test and fix the python CLI as well.

@rabbah - I'll create a separate issue for the multiple "error:" strings in the error message. #806

As for the `code` reference in the error message, this is the numeric `code` property returned in the failing HTTP response json.  Does this have particular diagnostic meaning for the CLI user?  Should this value be ignored in the error message?
Created an issue about missing test cases for the CLI already.
Comment modified. Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/4ac9d06816986c186a1c8a1429eeca9c5ccc517f.

Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/5af8cca8850131ac548a8e95784279b15088cf78.

@csantanapr Yes.
I am narrowing down the scope for the tests now into:

```
#       deleted:    tests/src/packages/SamplesTests.java
#       deleted:    tests/src/packages/SlackTests.java
#       deleted:    tests/src/packages/UtilsTests.scala
#       deleted:    tests/src/packages/websocket/WebSocketTests.scala
#       **deleted:    tests/src/services/HeadersTests.scala**
#       deleted:    tests/src/system/basic/CLIActionTests.java
#       deleted:    tests/src/system/basic/CLIJavaTests.scala
#       deleted:    tests/src/system/basic/CLIPythonTests.scala
#       deleted:    tests/src/system/basic/CLIRuleTests.java
#       deleted:    tests/src/system/basic/CLISequentialTests.java

```

I still need to look at HeadersTests.scala and ContainerPoolTests.scala, because they are not quite related to catalog, but will fail without catalog installation. The others definitely need to be move to openwhisk-catalog.

There are several of these that should NOT be moved. Anything in whisk/core should not move. Anything in system/baisc should not be moved. HeadersTests should not be moved. If these tests fails without catalog, then they should be made to work (by adding whatever assets they need to the tests/dat directory and creating the required assets as part of the test harness).

May I suggest that instead of whole sale moving packages and tests suites that you do this incrementally? Move exactly 1 package and its corresponding suite at a time. You''ll be thankful later to do it this way. @csantanapr FYI.
Yes it should be there in the error message. Note that for other error message the code is nicely formatted.
Perhaps the information needed above should be included in the README?
Will add this to the missing test coverage issue as well.
Missing test for creating an action without a source file: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/805.

I had missed it too. Combining your ideas: what if the build only adds the version timestamp if the variable is defined, defaulting to `SNAPSHOT` otherwise? Fast builds for devs, properly timestamped for releases?
Even if documented - The default way of building should be the pessimal route.
this isuee is not valid anymore.
We can go that route.  Is there a good gradle property or environment var already set by the production systems that identifies the build as a production build?
@mdeuser, taking this one.

@rabbah - Since the issue results contain two different `code` values (actual action code sent to server, numeric error code in server response).  I wanted to to be sure we are talking about the same `code` value wrt the nice formatting of its value.  Currently, the Go CLI formats the numeric code value as `(code N)` at the end of the error message when an error response is received from the server, so any other error message should have this value formatted in the same manner.
Are those values available at gradle time?  I was under the impression those were set during the ansible deployment phase.
Suggest we close this and hold off until we have a more stable Swift3 release?
My eyes failed me. `(code N)` was what I was expecting but saw only the first`code` and stopped reading.

The build does generate this file at some point - can't run tests without it. @markusthoemmes @lehoanganh without ant, when will this file be generated and will the values above be available to gradle?
Yes, I'm fine closing until the snapshot is more stable.
pg build 212
@psuter - assigning to you since you own #78 as well.  I made some simple tweaks to the commit from #78 so it would apply to the current code base.

Sound good.  The `(code N)` will continue to be in error messages (display by the CLI) that originate from the server.  Are these values described/documented yet?  If not, I'll open a doc issue for it
rebased/merged

In the meantime, I'll change the timestamp generation to no longer use the docker ARG as the build timestamp so that build times are improved.  I'll open an issue for discussion of whisk-wide build timestamps to see if and how build timestamps should be generated and used.

@dubeejw - Another one for review.  Basically setting the date in dockerfile (not obtaining from global setting) per your earlier comment.  https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/759#issuecomment-228495666
